captions.text:
Hey, Vsauce, Joey here. Sonic the Hedgehog-
every gamer knowns him. But, I ask you to

consider the implications of a human-sized
blue hedgehog that can run at supersonic speeds.
It's time to explore the science of Sonic.

But first, a question: How fast can Sonic
run, officially? Well, some games show Sonic

running at up to 5 times the speed of sound,
or more. Plus, there's that whole lightspeed

dash which explicitly states that he can move
at the speed of light. But, according to Einstein's

Theory of Special Relativity, that would mean Sonic either
has no mass or uses infinite energy.

Both options give me a headache, so, let's
stick with the possibilities that don't break
physics.

At the very least, there's consistent proof
over the years that Sonic moves at least at

the speed of sound, which is 768 MPH, or 343
m/s at sea level. This is otherwise known

as Mach 1, and each multiple of the speed
of sound is Mach 2, Mach 3, and so on.

Some real life references might be helpful.
Normal hedgehogs are known to sprint up to

6 MPH, less than 1% of Mach 1. The record
for fastest human goes to Usain Bolt, who

can run up to 27 MPH. The fastest land animal
in the real world is the Cheetah, which has

a top speed of 75 MPH, or about 1/10th of
Sonic speed. And the fastest animal on the

planet is the Peregrine Falcon, which, in
a full dive, can reach 200 MPH, about 1/4th
of Mach 1.

So, it turns out that there's nothing in nature
that really comes close to Sonic the Hedgehog.

So, what effects might breaking the sound
barrier have on an unprotected hedgehog? Well,

Sonic's about the weight and height of a small
human, so, let's treat him as such.

On October 14th, 2012, Felix Baumgarnter became
the only human to travel faster than the speed

of sound without the aid of a vehicle. You
can try this at home by skydiving from a height
of 39 KM.

Felix reached the speed in an atmosphere that
was thinner than what we experience at sea

level, meaning that the speed of sound was
slower where he was. However, he still achieved

Mach 1.24, so, his experience is useful. For
one, there was no undue stress on him caused

by breaking the sound barrier- Felix didn't
even notice it.

People don't feel velocity, they feel acceleration,
which is the change in velocity. If you're

traveling down the highway at a constant speed,
you'll feel the same forces as you would sitting

on a park bench. But, come to a sudden stop,
and you'll feel that change in acceleration.

Roller Coaster's can accelerate people at
up to 2 or 3 times Earth's gravity, known

as a "G." Military pilots are conditioned
to handle combat maneuvers at up to 7 G's,
which would make most people black out.

Attributing the same limitations to Sonic,
we find that he can go from 0 to Mach 1 in

about 5 seconds without fear of losing consciousness.
And that holds for slowing down, too.

But, if there's one thing that people know
about supersonic travel, it's the "sonic boom."

An object creates a series of pressure waves
when it moves through the air- much like a

boat in water. These waves travel at the speed
of sound, and, as the object, itself, breaks

the sound barrier, they're compressed into
a shockwave cone that travels behind the object.

Plane's often cause sonic booms, but would
Sonic, himself, cause a sonic boom? If we

go back to good ol' Felix, he gives us some
insight. He did create his own sonic boom,

but, it was a relatively quiet one. There
exists a figure to characterize the intensity

of sonic booms, called the "Figure of Merit."
Anything below a value of "1" is considered

an acceptable level of annoyance to observers.
The concord, a supersonic passenger jet, had

a value of 1.4. An object the size of Sonic,
or Felix, approaches a figure of merit of

"1" only in close proximity- within 5 meters
or so. Outside of that, you probably wouldn't

notice them at all. A humanoid simply doesn't
displace enough air to be a wide-ranging disturbance.

Another question involves Sonic talking at
Mach 1: Would you even be able to hear him?

Sonic, himself, and any friends traveling
at the same supersonic speed next to him,

would not be able to hear him at all, since
Sonic would be moving faster than the sound

escaping his mouth. Everyone's ears are situated
infront of the sound wave cone.

For stationary observers, anything Sonic says
would be compressed into that shockwave, and

just add noise to the previously discussed
sonic boom. And, besides, at Mach 1, he wouldn't

be able to say anything intelligeable anyhow.
In the time it takes me to say this sentence,

Sonic would have already travelled one mile.
It doesn't make for good communication.

Another thing to consider is that high speeds,
heating due to air friction, or, more specifically,

drag, becomes a concern. If you stick your
head out a car window going down the highway,
you've met drag-force.

Basically, air is dense enough to push back
on any object that enters through it at a

high speed. And that work done can create
heat. The question is, is this heat significant
enough to effect Sonic?

As speed increases, the drag-force that an
object needs to overcome is squared. Take

an object the size of Sonic, assume he's a
sphere, not hard to imagine, and this force

can reasonably be fully converted into thermal
energy. Using that assumption, Sonic would

heat up at a rate of 37 degrees Celsius, per
second.

Now, this is a rough number and doesn't account
for factors that would make Sonic cooler or

warmer, like convective cooling through the
atmosphere, or adiabatic heating, respectively.

One could convincingly argue that the heating
Sonic experiences would only be a fraction

of this because of the cooling effect of the
wind whipping by his face. But, it gives us

a good idea of the forces that Sonic needs
to work against on a daily basis.

This actually makes more sense in the context
of the short sprints Sonic utilizes. He can

only run for so long before he needs to cool
off for a bit. The real life effects of such

heating can be seen with the SR71 Blackbird.
It generated so much heat while flying at

Mach 3, that its titanium skin plates were
designed with gaps in between them that actually

leaked fuel while sitting at rest. But, this
design allowed the heated plates to expand

during flight and fill the gaps, ensuring
supersonic travel didn't tear the skin apart.

So, with all that in mind, I have one more
question: How much energy would Sonic expend

to run at the speed of sound? Everyone knows
that jogging is great exercise, so, hey, Mach
1 probably really sheds the pounds.

Well, there are two really relevant forces
at work here: The first is the energy Sonic

uses to move his legs- literally get up and
go. Using a Harvard health study that shows

calories burned while running, we could extend
that data out from 10 MPH to 760. Granted

it's very sketchy to extrapolate data, linearly,
that far, but, it's the best approximation

we've got. That said, we could expect Sonic
to burn about 2500 calories if he runs at

the speed of sound for 2 minutes. That's about
the average of what it would take him to run

through a stage at full speed; however, that
darn drag-force means that Sonic must expend

more energy to simply push back against the
air.

The power needed to overcome this force is
cubed as speed increases. And, since power

is the rate at which energy is used, we can
find the energy needed in calories, as well.

So, to overcome air drag, Sonic needs to burn
an extra 210,000 calories every 2 minutes.

To put that in perspective, Sonic would need
to consume 686 chili dogs every time he runs

through a full stage at supersonic speed.
That's almost 62,000 M&M's, or 386 Big Macs.
Hopefully Sonic has a pretty healthy appetite...

So, there are plenty of strange consequences
of supersonic speed, whether you're in a plane,

a pressurized suit, or red sneakers. But,
if you're traveling by sneaker, don't forget

to stash an extra bag of M&M's in your pocket.
And, as always, thanks for watching.

Do you need even more video game related videos?
Come to my own personal YouTube channel at

Clan of the Gray Wolf. I've got reviews, retrospectives,
explanations of video game tech. Ahh come
on over, we'll have a ton of fun.
